Looking to cover a lot of the town’s main
attractions, we set out on a city walking
tour.
Our first stop was the Dungan Mosque.

This mosque is unique because architecturally
it looks a lot like a Buddhist temple; this

is because it was built by the Dungan community,
an ethnically Chinese people group who follow
Islam.

Another iconic place of worship in Karakol
(Каракол) is the Holy Trinity Russian
Orthodox Church.

This is a traditional Russian wooden cathedral
complete with onion domes.

If you’re an avid souvenir collector then
you’ll want to swing by the Antique Shop
of Aleksandr Korablev.

This little one-room shop is overflowing with
treasures from the Soviet era.

They have old cameras, pins from the Russian
Olympics, porcelain dolls, old postcards,

busts of Lenin, and just about anything you
could imagine.

So we found an antique shop specializing in
items from the USSR.
And so talk about quirky.

Our future home somewhere.

As far as day trips go, one nearby attraction
from Karakol (Каракол) is Jeti Oguz
known for its red hills.

It’s about a 30 minute drive and you can
easily hire a driver to take you out there.

So we just finished visiting Jeti-Ögüz which
is a rock formation that translates into the

seven bulls and it is basically like these
red hills.

Um and it looks pretty cool and I thought
that was kind of like the main attraction

in the area but apparently you can also go
horse trekking here and the scenery is once
again amazing.

Jeti Oguz gets all the fame, but the valley
directly behind it is even more impressive
in my opinion.

If you’re visiting for the day, do as the
locals do and pack yourself a picnic.

We also noticed there were a few yurt camps
in the area, which is great for anyone wanting
to stay a bit longer.

And if you’re up for a longer outing, it’s
only 1 additional hour from Jeti-Ögüz to

the Barskoon Gorge, which is home to numerous
waterfalls and hiking trails.

You’ll know you’ve arrived once you reach
the bust of Yuri Gagarin (Юрий Гагарин),

the first cosmonaut, standing proud just off
the main road.

Apparently, he was quite fond of Issyk Kul’s
(Иссык-Куль) south shore and even

spent some time vacationing here after his
first flight into space.

And it wouldn’t be a proper drive in Kyrgyzstan
(Кыргызстан) without encountering

a little bit traffic…sheep and goat traffic,
that is.
(Honking sounds and animals noises)

Last but not least, one of the most popular
things to do in Karakol (Каракол) is
hiking.

This is considered the adventure capital of
Kyrgyzstan (Киргизия) with many hikes
and horse treks starting right in town.

We were feeling pretty wiped having just completed
a 3-day horse trek, so we took the easy route

and did a half-day hike, but the landscapes
were stunning nevertheless.

Alright, so we hopped in the car, drove out
of town and now we're getting some great panorama
views of Karakol off in the distance.
